text:
Old Odense Ale is a collaborative brew as Sam Calagione from Dogfish Head have participated in. The ale is made by an old receipt from Odense in Denmark, and it contains lots of spicy notes. Its a bit difficult to put names on the spices.
It smells very little of the familiar musty aroma of wet horse stables, as wild yeast Brettanomyces are known for. It is very vinous while mouthwatering ale that are very varied in its taste. Acid is high, but in a pleasant way in which it works mouth-cleaning and does not leave long tasting notes in the mouth afterwards. It is surprisingly fresh and comfortable.

Bottle shared at Daves tasting. Pours a very hazy reddish brown with a tan head. Pleasant aroma of figs and caramel but really not much else. The flavor is more complex than the aroma suggests with a touch of balsamic vinegar, figs, dates, and caramel. Very nice. Mild-moderate bitterness at the finish. A touch of alcohol at the finish as well. Enjoyable.

Bottle (thanks to goodbyeohio)... Poured dark brown with a little head. Nose of slight oxidation with a strong maple front. Maple and dark brown sugars were evident with a light, thin acidity and sourness creeping in. This aged gracefully. Dark fruits and vinous tones added complexity.

20.3oz bottle, shared by Caterwaul. Code on bottle reads "TAP 140208 MHT 110210" - dont know what that means, but this is probably at least several years old. Totally hazy red / brown color. Thin, bubbly, sort of beige colored head. Dots of lace. Interesting, potent aroma. Big raisin, fig, cranberry. caramel malt. Blackberries and spice, much more noticeable in the flavor, with a hint of maple syrup as well.. Makes me think of pancakes a bit, but much more herbal, bitter, and spicy. Theres a pretty impressive level of bitterness here, moderate to stronger bitter. A somewhat acidic balsamic vinegar overtone to it all, pretty assertive. Impressively tart, too. Medium body. Kind of crisp, lighter carbonation, lightly dry texture. Pretty tasty gruit, very flavorful and complex. I liked it much more than expected.

Shared with DrSilverworm. Cloudy brownish red. White lacing. Smells very fruity with raisins, figs, and dates at the front. Smells vinegary and creamy, too. Faint medicinal/herbal scent. Black cherry in the taste supported by raisin, date and fig notes. Tart. Balsamic, but also quite sweet. Well balanced, even now. Almost chocolatey at times. Neat! Spritzy and effervescent. Good bitterness. Hint of bubblegum? Hmm... Pretty singular stuff. If you can find it, its definitely worth a try.

50 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20091107.
Pours brown color with a small head. Aroma of malts, some spice notes, yeast, wooden and earthy notes and some caramel. Flavor of ripe fruits, spices, malts, caramel and wood.

60 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 07.11.2009
Aroma is sourish with currant juice, some berries and tartness. Flavour is somewhat sour and tart with redcurrants, berries, distant woody notes and syrup. Reminds me of some oud bruin beers. Quite unique, it took two bottles to not hate this (2.6->3.5).

A hazy copper pour with a white head. Slight cardboard on the nose along with some strange tartness. A bit of an herbal note, pine, maple syrup, and some spice. Light berry fruit character, bread, and apple cider. The flavor is all over the place as well. Some oxidation, light sourness, lots of pine, herbs, and spice. Sweet apple, toast, and bread with just a bit of berry. A hint of alcohol, tea, and cider. Not sure what to think of this one.

One of my favorite beers ever had it in mid 2011 so aged 4 years. Just a wonderful blend of flavors.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ the brewpub. Rated on 6.10.2011.
Pours a hazy orange colour with a small white head. Aroma of strong sour fruits, berries and some yeast. Flavour of sweet, strong, sour fruits, sweet malts, dry hops and grapefruit. Long, sour, mouth-drying finish. Very tasty.
On tap at KØ-2011. Red deep golden colour with an off-white head. aroma is sour, malt, fruit, alcohol. flavour is sour, malt, fruit, alcohol, citrus. Nice beer.

bottle... medium copper with a red hue, light tan head... smells like warm apple cider witha  bit of liquor, some nutmeg like spice... tastes like light apple juice with tea and a bit of pine, so-so, the mouthfeel is a bit too light... so-so

Auction.

Hazy / amber pour with aromas of spice, bread and fruit. Taste is is similar with a thick sour finish. Good.
Hazy orange with a small off White head. Strong sour Wood aroma, heather honney and suger. Acidic flavor, herbs, flowers, honney dry sour wood. Dry sour finish. Special brew
Bottle. Pours amber brown. Tan head. Nose/taste of maple syrup, tart black berry, figs, black licorice and anise. Mild tartness. Light sour herbal berry finish. Medium body. Great balance.
Sampler at CBF 2011-06-28. Clear orange with am off-white film. Berries, fruits and vinegar aroma. Sour, fruity and acidic flavor with apples present. Medium body. Finishes dry.
Draught at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011. Clear brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of fruit, spice, yeast, malt and wood.
Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, yeasty and tart. Flavor is quite sweet, moderate bitter and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 270511

Tap sample @ Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011. Clear nut brown, small white head. Nose is faint tones of vinegar and green apples, hints of wood and strawberries. Taste is vinegar, strawberry jam, wood and grapes. Interesting. Strawberry jam/marmelade in liquid form is the closest thing I get to describe this beer. Nothing too great here, but I gotz to give propz for originality as the custom is among my people. :-P
At Copenhagen Beer Festival. Orange-brown colour. Fresh, fruity and spicy aroma and flavour, only moderately sour. Quite nice.
nose is sweet alcohol, sweet pineapple, canesugar, mediumweak hops, feel is thin, carb is medium, taste is soursweet, teriyaki, acidic notes, green apples

Tasting at Dawsons.  Rich amber pour with little head.  Only had a little, but it was full of character.  Strong bitter aroma, but great malty flavors.  Well balanced.  Will definitely get it again soon.

A brown orange ale with a thin dark moka head. In aroma, a lambic-like sour aroma with maple and vanilla notes, oaken. In mouth, a soursih ale with oak chips, lactic points, wooden barrel. A bit light and strange. Bieropholie imports, tasted Dec. 24 2010.

20th February 2009 Cloudy orange - brown beer. Brewed with Star Anise, Black Thornberries, Maple Syrup and Herbs - a 15th Century Gruit recipe. Sharp crisp beer. An almost lemony start but with no real acidity - fruity. Just a slight hint of herbs in the sharp semi dry finish. Unique tasting beer - really tickles the taste buds.

Sampled @ Copenhagen Beer Festival 2010. Hazy orange body with a small off-white head. Aroma is slightly acidic fruity with caramel. Flavor is mild acidic, fruity, sweet and medium bitter. A bit unusually but I enjoyed it.
Aroma is sour, spicy and berryful. Maybe juniper berries. Flavour has lots of herbs and sourness. ANd definitely juniper. Nice oily and smooth, low carb. Strange but nice.
Nice amber to copper golden/red with a fizzy white head.  Sweet and sour fruit aroma with caramel notes.  Earthy green apple and mild sour taste with some candy notes to the finish.  Pretty good.

Draught. Orange/amber coloured. Dense light beige head. ARoma is sourish, has berries and light spice and fruits. Flavou is full of berries and light yeast and a grapy sourness. Medium bodied. Dry grapy end.

On tap. Hazy orange body with a small off white head. The aroma is vinous, vinegar and figs. Some caramel and fruit. The flavour is acid, caramel, fruit and berries. Creamy texture. Sour sweet berry finish.

Draught at DBF 2010.
Hazy reddish with a small head almost immediately gone. Aroma light malty (spicy, fir, fruity) moderate to heavy acidic/sour. Flavor light sweet, moderate sour and spicy. Medium body, almost flat. Fine and interesting.

Interesting brew that begins with a murky rose gold color that produced a small eggshell head.  Tons of dark cherry skin, pepper, biscuit and honey both in aroma and flavor.  Cherry was dominant.  Medium to velvety mouthfeel...not my thing but unique non-the-less.

Aroma of white vinegar, fruits ,yeast and mild funk. Pours a murky amber color with almost no head. The flavor is sour, theres also vinegar, fruits, yeast and mild funk. The body is light to medium with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Quite interesting.

Bottle sampled on 8/24/08: Pours a slightly hazy copper orange with a thin ring of off-white head.  Tart nose of oak and cherries with a touch of sweet biscuity caramel.  Body starts with good fullness and pale malty sweetness with pleasant earthy light fleshy fruity balance and pine notes before a drier, semi-tart finish.  Pretty smooth with good complexity throughout.  An enjoyable and unique brew.

Hazy orange and spakling beer. Thin white head. The aroma is acidic and it has sour apples. Maple syrup and caramle sweetness in the finsih. The taste is sour and acidic. Dry, quite tart finsish. Long aftertaste. Medium bodied palate, sugary texture.

Bottle and served in my Duval snifter: Slightly muddy brown with a frothy head which left good lace upon the glassware. The aroma is unique to say the least, I get all kinds of esters and vapours here to include: cherry pits, black berry, fig, maple syrup, marzipan, anise, woodruff, peat, mineral water, spruce tips, band-aid and even a touch of Pediococcus. The taste is interesting as well and layered with twangy fruits and barnyard snap, spicy notes, earthy smoky and peaty notes and a base of sweet syrupy malt. This is one of those magical beers where the wild sourness actually works and make it a joy to drink. Let say I am digging this... I am not too sure if I bought another bottle it would be the same but I can only rate what is in front of me. Yet another of those Danish brews that are not on everyones wishlist but far exceeds my expections. Perhaps it is the lesser beers from these breweries that actually make me want to visit someday soon.  One part traditional ale, one part olde ale and one part Flemish sour. YUMMY!

20091120  500ml bottle from State Line.  caramel, cereal, nuts, spruce, herbs, dough, earthy, leaves, clove, ginger, licorice, smoke, woody, pale, orange, red, amber, cloudy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, creamy, sticky, lively, soft carbonation, astringent, long finish.

Delicious, surprising stuff.  Not too sweet, not too tart, super drinkable.  No idea what I was getting into with this one, but now I wish I had bought more.

.5 liter bottle shared by Willblake.  Pours a peach- hazy copper with a thin white head- light lace.  Aroma is thick short stubby pine needles- juicy, almost a strange sour-lambic note, without getting too funky- juicy lactic- citrus, lime-like, with salted pork fat, juniper berry, and blackberry.  Flavor is light lime, margherita rock salt, orange juice, berry- blackberry, cranberry, fruit juicy with a nice earthy woody tartness, lemon-lime, pine, and tartaric acid.  Smooth with a nice tartness, incredibly drinkable. Very unique beer but very good.

600 ml bottle. Finland.
Hazy dark brown colour with small off-white head. Sweet and sour spicy herbal aroma with some berries. Sweetish sour herbs, yeast, resin and berries. Interesting brew.

Draught at Københavns Øldage 2009, Valby. Pours a dark golden amber color with a thin off-white head. Has a sweetish spicy herbal aroma with some light smoky hints. Sweetish spicy herbal and funky flavor. Has a sweetish fruity spicy herbal finish.

Cheers to tpd975 for sharing this one.
Pours golden/orange with quickly disappearing beige head.
Aroma hints of maple, some malts and herbal scents coupled with the freshness of anise.
Flavor, intense berry mouthfeel and palate, some candi sugar, yeasty with some herbal notes and maple.
Light spicy finish with hints of berry tartness.

Thanks to tpd975 for bringing this along. It pours rutty apricot with gold  copper hues and thin off white head. Interesting aroma with notes of spices, apricots, berries and red apple skins. The flavor has the same sort of components but with a thick viscous rich mouth feel to go along with the spices, berries, apples, sweet crystal like malts, a bit of mustiness and really no sign of herbs. This bottle was close to two years old so maybe the herb notes receded way into the background.

Bottle Courtesy of Tpd. Pours a hazy orange. Nose is lots of booze, tons of candy, apple, fruits, spices, almost a cordial flavor. Flavor is smooth fruity ethers, musky basement, tart fruits, cherries, plum, caramel and earthiness. Full bodied with a lingering sweetness. Very nice.

[2261-20090607] Sample. Sweet maple apple syrup and flower toffee aroma. Clear, brown amber body with a quick bubbly head. Sugary sweet toffee continues in the flavour with a long sweet malt finish and some apple flower hints. Full body. Interesting, hides the alcohol well.
(4T @ Mondial 2009; Montreal, QC)

another one by way of the psprings i dont want to carry all this beer back drinkathon...

the pour is reminiscent of murky brandy... brownish coppery amber with a thin tan head. 

enticingly strange aroma... like someone is smoking clove cigarettes next to a heap of rotting silage and over ripe fruit beginning to sour... toss in some flowers, brown sugar, star anise, berries and eucalyptus to make it even more confusing.

the flavor is the same and equally perplexing. its all over the place weird... sour, sweet, spiced, fruity and down right odd. but, not in a negative way. i seriously want to figure this thing out!

the body is light to medium but has some syrupy richness. carbonation is low. mouth feel is crisp from tartness. idk...8/4/7/3/16/3.8

Way bizarre.  Bottle at Atlas courtesy of psprings.  Pours a murky brown with a trim tan head.  Smells like a spice rack and tastes like a fermented wild berry Capri-Sun.  Menthol, too?  Definitely a memorable, if not confounding, brew.

Bottle.  Pours a large, frothy, off white-light brown, diminishing head.  Somewhat murky, amber body.  Sour, sweaty, tangy aroma - herbal with sweet caramel malt and all kinds of spices.  Star anise, dark sugar, alpine woodsy and some wild berries.  A little earth mixed in for good measure.  Flavor is the same, but intensified.  Medium bodied, creamy, and slightly sticky at the finish.  Somewhat lively carbonation.  Overall a really fun and enjoyable beer.

Bottle from Premiere Gourmet. Masterful creation, with no detectable hops. A good sourness supported by the spices, there is depth. Smooth, soft carbonation. Unfiltered. Good spice I like star anise and it was not an obstacle. Some soapy head, nice and off white, lacey. Spicey and sour and herbal aroma. In a word, balance.

Bottle.  Spicy nose (earthy notes remind of pumpkin), hugely malty with some tree needles and cherry and light vinegar.  Dark orange-amber beer with an orange-tinged beige head.  Tart, acidic body with light chocolate under the sour wooden tones, some sweetness and star anise with spruce and kriek.  Medium, filling body, smooth with light carbonation and a tangy aftertaste.  Alcohol hidden completely except for the subtle and pleasant warming in the chest and cheeks after some volume.  Vanilla and light citrus, spruce-like notes and (gale?).  Currant, nutmeg, touch of apple.  You bitches are crazy for not loving this!  Right up my alley, a mild sour ale in the gruit mold, up with the best of the Belgians.

Hazy light brown color with a fizzy head at first that recedes quickly.  Aroma is slightly sour, some tart red fruit, and a touch of caramel.  Flavor is tart up front then becomes quite malty, with a bit of maple and fruit.  Some wood flavors in the finish.  Watery body.  Pretty nice, somewhat unique.

Murky orange in colour with a thin quick to dissipate white head, light lacing.  The aroma is sweet and spicy, herbal, some berries, peaty.  The flavour is sweet upfront with a weird mix of spices, peat malt continues, lots of berries, earthy.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes long, sweet with some light smoke.
This was very weird right from the start but that was expected in a collaboration  between these two experimental breweries.  Easily the most confusing beer Ive had.  One moment I loved it and the next moment it becomes too much.
650ml bottle from Belmont Party Supply in Dayton, Ohio.
Opened on December 19, 2008.
Best before February 11, 2010.

In short: A peculiar ale with an all-over-the-place flavour spectrum.  Unpleasantly weird.
How: From the bottle at Montreal Mondial de la Bière 2009
The look: Almost clear copper body with almost no head
In long: The nose is all over the place with a with a weird sourness, some herbs, notes of white wine and a little countryside field.  Taste is nothing but boring, this is a tasty beer, almost intense.  Sour grapes, honey, tree sap, vinous feeling, barnyard character, medium sourness, and I could go on and on  Basically this is a bunch of not-cohesive flavours thrown at me as hard as possible.  This is not a good beer, really not, yet I found it captivating and I can imagine drinking a full pint of this stuff, making faces after every sip trying to figure what the hell this is.  This beer is as fucked-up yet also as intriguing as this dude explaining to you how the NFL is plotting to assassinate Al Gore because they want to open franchises in Alaska and Yukon.

Bottle - Mondial de la Bière, Montréal. Dark gold hazy body with a fair white foamy head. Complex malty/hoppy aroma with flowery, grainy and citrusy hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Well balanced taste that carries some spicy notes and ends with a long, robust bitter finish. Well done.

Bottle @ Mondial de la Biere 2009 
Appearance:  gold-amber look , fine haze , some lighter fizzy top.3- Nose: Slight sourness , funky character, bit citric , farmyard , vanilla finish. Hint of old cask with alcohol dip. 6+.Flavor/Palate :  Mid bodied. Slight malts with zesty lemony feel with hint of farm funk. Softer finish. Old ale = farm ale? Late berry feel hinted with vanilla cask.

2009-06-07. Dark amber body is headless, very little carbonation makes me suspect that the bottle has been open at the booth for a while. (3+) Aroma is interesting, vinous not quite sour tang to it, light fruit and mild sugar undertones, modest malt. (7+) First sip is bracing refreshing sourness (which probably says as much about early in the day it was as the beer), while the second adds much more malt and fruit to the mix. Lingering light sourness reminds me a little bit of the Rodenbach Vin de Céréale, or at least my memory of it. Smooth average to medium body. Decent. Bottle, Mondial 2009, Montreal
aroma of sweet malt, sour mash, and some hops. Flavor is odd.......its tart, and sour but there is some piney resins in there. Weird.

Bottle @ Mondial 2009.

  Aroma is a boozy sweet malt, orange liqueur, dark amber, small white head.  Taste is syrupy, humbugs. Light bodied, cloying almost harsh. Disappointing.

Bu au Mondial 2009, le 5 juin (#17). Rousse cuivrée brumeuse, pas de collet. Arome dorge sucré et de fruit un peu sûrette. Goût très fruité sûrette, un peu de malte sucré, larrière-goût est un peu sec. Agréable sans être intance!

Another sour-like ale from the brewhouse shared with faroeviking from tap at CBF 09. Pale orange. Bubbles on the surface. Aroma of tart berries and fruits. Cherry-like taste followed by caramel malts. Dry and quite smooth on the palate. Works alright, but has not got too much excitements (Valby, 15.05.2009).
On tap at Copenhagen beer festival.  Poured a dark gold, a bit cloudy. Head was off-white. Aroma had tart and hop notes. Flavor begins tart and ends sour, left a metallic taste in my mouth.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 tap Københavnske Øldage 2009
sweetish berries, aroma.
stale berries flavor, sourness and bitterness.
[6,3,6,3,11]
-
re-rate tap 2011 cph beerfestival.
clear orang,e small yellow head. nice tart and fruity sourish aroma, caramle, good balance, wood, vanlilla. flavor is tart, soursih, wood, fruity, lovely.[7-3-8-3-17]
Draught. Amber colour. Sweet bit smoked tart spiced aroma. Sweet and tart, berry, spiced and hoppy bitter flavour with a light smoke touch.
Golden with at white head. Aroma is malty, and has some sour notes, maybe from some berries. Taste is strange sour.

500mL Bottle. Maple aroma hits you as the deep amber brew settles with little head. An acetic tart aroma with a hint of pineapple after the huge maple and licorice. Flavor is complex and sour, with a thick finish that is easy to like.
Bottle. Thin short lived head. Dark orange amber. Sour cherry-orange aroma. Flanders cherry oak flavour, a little citrusy. Enjoyable moderate sourness with a building citrus.
sample at Beer Bistro Danish Dinner, Toronto. Orange amber pour. Funky, sour, fruity aromas. Taste is fruit kriekish sour. Some funk in there. Cherry sour.Strange herbalness Interesting
odd amber color, some white foam. nose is very very dogfish esk. kinda sweet with definate spicy notes. Taste is tart almost has sour notes, very funky almost barn yard. and an odd hoppy finish.

500 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy orange amber color with a medium sized off white head.  The aroma has a definite sweet sour thing going on with oranges, cherries, and berries, some caramel malt, and a touch of yeast.  The flavor has some sweeter fruit (cherry and berries) up front that becomes more tart in the finish.  There is a caramel malt backbone that tries to add balance.  This was easy to drink with its medium mouthfeel and interesting blend of flavors.

2/11/2009:  Old Odense Ale has a cloudy, deep golden orange color with a quickly fading ivory-colored head.  It has a really attractive sweet, but tart, sour, and acidic aroma dominated by a tart cherry quality.  The flavor is also sweet but tart with a hefty caramel maltiness nearly hidden under a layer of tart/sour cherry/berry flavor.  Overall the flavors are well-balanced and this beer is extremely easy to drink.  I would call this a "session sour" if such a term existed.  Some of the herbal quality comes through in the finish.  There is a lot going on in this beer, but it is all good and not overly complex.  I really like it.  It also has a good mouthfeel and quite enjoyable overall.

50 cl bottle (7.5% alc/vol; TAP 140208 / MHT 110210; BDanish sour gruit ale brewed with star anise, blackthorn berries, maple syrup and herbs) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #104 for this beer.
Bottle. Ruddy brown with a stable head. Tart aroma with raisins, berries and spices. Good spiced sweet and sour flavours, well-balanced, tart fruit, very complex. Dry finish. Highly original.

20.3 ounce bottle from State Line Liquors. Pours a vibrant and hazy deep orange color. Medium tan head shows good retention and lacing. Tart aroma with notes of toffee, raisins, anise and other spices, maple and citrus. Taste is also tart with notes of citrus, toffee, honey, wood, scuppernongs, caramel and spice. Full bodied. Very complex and very good.

1 pt. 4.3 oz. bottle. Clear amber, fluffy and durable white head, but only spotty lace. Vinous nose, some woodiness and a faint herbal character. Medium body and carbonation, dry, clean palate. Acidic and sour, only a very light malty sweetness detectable,, and no noticeable bitterness. Quite strange, but drinkable.

Compliments of DrBayern!  Pours turbid orange with 2-finger off-white head. Nose is of tart fruit, including cherry, berry, spicy yeast, honey, juniper. Tastes tart, fruity, with some earthy notes, hops, honey, spice, and orange zest flavours. There is a defined herbal disposition upfront and throughout with glimpses of cedar and tea. The finish is mildly soured.  Interesting beer from our friends in Denmark.  Thanks Matt!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Hazy orange color with quickly vanishing white head. A little lace. Sour, apple-like aroma with  some vinegar and sweetish notes. Flavor is somewhat odd: sweet and sour fermented apple with syrupy finish. Medium-bodied, quite harsh, acidic and somwhatcarbonated palate.

Bottle from Belmont Party.

Poured a hazy orange/brown color with an average off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Good aroma of spice,yeast, citrus and maple. Medium body with smooth texture and lively carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet&sour flavor with a complex sweet finish of medium duration. 

Interesting complex brew.

Hazy light umber color with a moderate amount of dark cream colored bubbles. Quite fruity in aroma, nearly like a kriek with some spice and vanilla. I find it quite balance and enjoyable to sniff. There is a pine quality underneath that grows as this one set. LIght and airy on the palate. Slightly tart in the start with some strawberry flavors. Also catch some rhubarb and figs. Only slightly spicy, with hints of star anise and allspice. I find this a very enjoyable spiced brew. The finish is a little sweet, but the acidity throughout wells combat that. This is my type of holiday brew.
Sampled at Backus Backyard Bash. Hazed amber with a small white head. Spicy and slightly sour nose, fruity. Somewhat flat, but sweet and tasty.

Nice chunky, hazy deep copper coloured body with ruby highlights, a lot of sediment and a very small tan head. Aroma of interesting scents - pine, yeast, oak, vanilla, lemon rind and a bit of hay & grass. Medium-bodied; Strong assertive taste up front of malt, lemons, berries and a bit of nuts. Mellowing out after a few seconds shows an almost gueuze-like sourness, some yeast and a little sweetness. Overall, a very complex and entertaining beer - I had no idea which way this beer was going to turn out, but it was a nice one to try! I sampled this 600 mL bottle (at $15.49) purchased from West LakeView Liquors in Chicago, Illinois on 15-December-2008, sampled at home in Washington on 03-February-2009.
Pours clear amber/copper into a shaker.  Head quickly recedes to hug rim. Peach and pit fruit aromas.  Tart and cider-like upfront. Earthy in the middle and sour citrus in the finish.

Pours a two finger cream head that fades quickly to a ring leaving no lace.  Murky, cloudy amber color.  Light carbonation and medium bodied. Sour apple nose. Flavor is balanced to tart fruit/apple with a clean finish. Not bad but a disappointing old ale, I was expecting more maltiness. Wicked expensive at $18.00 for a 600ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Date: October 17, 2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: hazy burnt orange, frothy beige head
Aroma: funkyand  moldy aroma with a tart fruityness, musty oak and lemon
Flavor: sweet and fruity malt flavor, nice tartness, light earthyness, light bitter finish
Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: *4

1 pt 4.3 oz bottle enjoyed at Uber Tavern in Seattle. Pour is orange, ruby, brown with a thinnish off white head. Aroma of blackberry, lactic sourness, and light caramel maltiness. Interesting nose. Taste is sour berry, citrus lemons some grainy huskiness. Palate is medium to syrupy, clean finish despite the multiple flavors. This was unlike anything i have had. Interesting, different, fully enjoyable.

Bottled. Tart aroma, quite enjoyable, but I must say this smells a lot like the chicken with mustard sauce and artichokes I made the other night. Odd. I like it though, which is good, because I liked that dish, too. Flavor is a sweet malty tart, balanced and drinkable, some beets and grape skins and yeast in there. I guess I can see a little bit of the gruit in this, perhaps some juniper or something. Its a good beer, easy drinking and mellow with decent complexity, and very original.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dune bouteille de 500 ml, dégusté au festival Flaveurs, Bières et Caprices 2008 (Montréal, QC). Arôme: Légère odeur de vinaigre fruité. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de pomme légèrement sûrette avec une pointe dépices et de miel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement vinaigré. (Rating #2091)
Unclear amber of color with a nice offwhite head. An aroma of apples, sour, fruits and sweet. A flavor of fruits, apples, sour and dry.

On tap at European Beer Festival, Copenhagen. A clear, golden beer with a small, off-white head. Some fruityness in the aroma, sourness, alcohol and some sugars. Quite warming, full-bodied and effervescent in the mouth, with alcohol and a stinging sourness giving some lemon. Citrusy-sour finish. Nice in a way, but hard to pin and not my favorite. (080913
A bottle from Alko Jyväskylä. Fruity and raisin slightly sour nose. Sour taste. No sweetness. Slightly bitter sidetaste. Pale fast disappearing head. Hazy amber colour. Sour medicinlike taste.
Aroma very sweet, honey and syrup. Sour grape, balanced sweetness. Light acidty, lactic. extremely interesting brew, i really enjoyed this one.

1pt 4.3oz bottle poured into a snifter.

This one pours a deep murky amber with a little brown in the middle. There is a small off-white head that recedes quickly to a ring and leaves no lacing,

The aroma is very sweet with the berries, molasses and hints of the spices. The caramel malts are also present in the nose.

The taste has a little more tartness up front with a hint of funk and spices. The sweetness comes out in the middle with the malts underneath and the finish is slightly sweet.

The mouthfeel is slightly syrupy with little carbonation and the sweetness sticks on the palate between sips.

As usual, Sam has taken on an interesting style and made it fairly drinkable. This one isn’t one of my favorites but I’m glad I tried it.

Courtesy GodofThunder.  Slightly cloudy amber color, thin even off-white head.  Slightly lactic aroma, rich malts and caramel underneath, cut apple.  Sweeter fruity taste, slight sour finish.  Interesting.

It doesn’t surprise me after tasting this that Sam Calagione had something to do with the beer’s creation. It’s funky. There’s a slightly sour quality found in several Belgian styles. The spices are far from overwhelming and without their being listed on the label, I probably would have just assumed the slight spiciness was a trick of the yeast. Interesting beer that was well worth the one-time purchase.

Bottle@home

Apperance: Pours a golden-red color with a rather big head. Not much lacing on this one.

Aroma: Berries, Grapes, Vanilla, Honey, Raisin and several spices. Interesting to say the least.

Flavor: Tart, Honey, Spices, Raisin, Fruit, Herbs. Lots of stuff going on here.

Palate: Low carbonation. Interesting blend of sour and sweet notes. Very complex and unusual.

An interesting experience this beer. Very refreshing but also slightly heavy once you’ve had half a bottle. At 10E per bottle this is not i will be purchasing anytime soon. Recommended because of the interesting character.

Sampled during Minnesota first annual Sourfest and shared by Guerde. Pours a hazy orange amber brew with a thin off-white head that slowly dissipates to a thin white ring. Aroma of tart cherries, dry cotton candy, some citrus zest, and a touch of vanilla. Taste is medium bodied with plenty of carbonation with flavors of maple, tart fruit, vanilla and some spice. Finish is semi-dry with a wood and tart berry aftertaste.

500ml at Uber. Black with grainy ebony highlights. Virtually headless and laceless. Nice sour tart nose; maybe approaching a tangy pineapple sweet and sour sauce with balsamic thrown in. Nice grainy, nourishingly rich body. Hits you that the mysterious/hard-to-place quality of the nose is actually a cool combination of a bug sour and a berry sour together. Yummy. Easy drinking, harmonious, and super pleasant.

My Bottom Line:
This iconoclast of a strong ale presents a sensuous body in which dried white raisins, tart tropical fruit, wild, coniferous needles and bulky honeyed sweetness somehow work in unison. As memorable as it is curious, this one has to be sipped thoroughly to be understood.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam skirts the cloudy amber.
-Blended with honeyed sweetness, the sour fruit notes in the nose become strange.
-The wild, grassy notes taste like a cross of brettanomyces and pine.
-Tartness mostly shows up in the last half of the flavor profile, which works well, while being unexpected from the first front of the stip.

Bottle.
(EBF 2008)  Hazt golden color, small head. Vinous, sweetish aroma. Flavor brings sweet fruits, figs and raisins. Some alcohol showing.

This is one of those more interesting than enjoyable kinds of beers.  It pours a hazy amber body and for a short while has a tall yellow/beige head.  The aroma is like the tart cherries from the tree in my yard (40+ years back), some stale toffee, and sour milk... not unpleasant, but not really pleasing to my olfactory senses, either.  Full-bodied and tart on the tongue.  There’s an old caramel sweetness in the flavor, some sour cherrires and light berries, dried up herbs, sour milk, and earth.  Again, not unpleasant, but nothing that I really want to put into my mouth again.  I’m leaving it with an upper mid-range, even rating... and leaving that right quickly ’cause it seems to be unsettling my stomach.  Bye!Pat’s Liquors, Porter, IN

Hazy amber body, very creamy yellowish head; Very funny and pleasant nose, the fruits stands out very clear and are very fitting with the malt fill; Quite full body, super soft both texture and carbonation, bitter with a slight sweetness; Long finish, tons of aroma, fruits are very clear. Great beer!

Courtesy GodOfThunder.  Pours a hazy, glowing, golden-orange color with a small, foamy, off-white head.  Soapy spots of lacing mostly rejoin the body.  The nose displays a caramel and brown sugar malt base, followed by herbal notes of juniper berries, cinnamon, musty oak, and various green leaf varieties.  Flavors show a touch of sour wild berries, more caramel and brown sugar, with indiscernible, green herbal notes, and a hint of star anise.  Medium-plus on the palate and smooth, the finish is on the dry side.  Overall, this is a very interesting and fairly well executed brew.

thick looking murky orange/brown with great lacing under small frothy white head.  aroma of sour pineapple, strawberries, tea, oak, caramel.  flavor of  unripe berries, caramel, pine needles, peach syrup,  herbs.  tart and sour.  full bodied.  a little sweet.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2008 Thanks to FlacoAlto for the trade.  Poured a cloudy light brown with a little white head.  This is pretty complex, and tasty.  I get a lot of sweet berries, a little yeast and not much alcohol at all.  A good old ale with a little sourness.  Very smooth.  The forcefulness of the thornberries reminds me of the Schlitz Bull.  Uncompromising!  Overall, I really enjoyed this.  
(11/18/08 Addition)-Had this again and wanted to raise my rating.  I thought it was amazing.  The best of an Old Ale, a little Barleywine-esque, with some killer fruity sourness.  Really an original brew.
Tasting at mcbackus 10/19. Cloudy orange color.  Wood, sour, malty aroma.  Flavor is also woody and somewhat sour.  Not my favorite beer of the night.  But not bad either.
bottle, orange color with tan head, nose is sour, flavor is sour, woody, spice and vegetal, finish is sour

(600ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of cherry, whip cream, orange, pine, and wood.  Flavor of tremendously sweet cherry, oak, pine, and various spices with a dry finish.  Quite different.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2010 (On tap) Almost clear amber golden with a small, off-white head. Fresh and tart aroma. Medium-bodied, very fruity with a vague underlying sweetness. Very pleasant and balanced. 140908

Bottle. Poured a hazy orangish color an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of spices, maple syrup, herbal, berries, and candy-ish. Aromas were hard to nail down and different. Tastes of sour candy, fresh ever green trees, dark fruits, hearbal, and berries. Tart finish. Woody. Definitely different all the way around!

Bottle shared at Reuben’s Canadian Thanksgiving.  Pours a hazy ruby brown body with orange accents.  Notes of berries and other dark fruit.  A note of honey and a mild etoh warming.  Hints of wood and finishes dry.

Bottle. Sweet fruity aroma with sone spicey candy. Orange body with off white head. Carbinated body that packs some sout tart dryness to the brew. Fruity and detected something else that I had eperienced flavor of. It was the anise candy I use to have with me during hunting season in Nov in the north woods of Wisconsin. Moderate dryness left on palate from tart but decent brew.

Pours a hazy, ruddy, copper color with a moderate, pillowy, cola-like, cream-colored head; a very small, frothy layer remains leaving minimal, tight lace.  Nose is interesting to say the least; it is very hard to find every flavor but certainly the faint anise is there, maple as well, vanilla, herbs are soft and reminding me of thyme or rosemary, and an earthy-woodsy flavor which may be fir?  Underneath theses flavors is the sour notes of blackberry or red currant?  Flavor is surprisingly tart to begin with similar fruit notes of blackberry and overripe raspberry but a subtle earthy-woodsy flavor creeps in (fir bark?).  Very subtle spices find there way by the finish including thyme, maybe sage, and faint white pepper.  Very faint maple and anise also noted throughout.  Palate is medium, silky, nearly lively, and just a bit dry.  Finishes average, lightly dry, spicy with white pepper, lingering tartness, herbs and earthy wood disappating, and lingering faint maple note.  Wow, the ratings for this one are not a reflection of the beer itself.  The nose is much sweeter than the tart flavors on the tongue.  Complexity is great and use of special ingredients adds dimension and depth.  l loved the subtleties in the spicing, herbs, and earthen tones.  Truly unique among all beers and certainly deserving of more praise.

The reviews are not kind enough. This is a very nice sour ale. Lots of spice and pucker going on. My wife handed he glass back to me. All the better. Very drinkable. Not what I expected, but butter. The sour was the surprise.

Sampled at EBF08.
Hazy golden.
Sourish and vinous.
Raisin, prunes and figs.

On tap at EBF 08.  From a medieval recipe.  5 different spices.  Little bit of wood and sourness on aroma.  Very unusual, some fruit in there too.  Really stand out.  Raspberry, sharp fruit in the mouth.  Woody spices are good.  Interesting.  Bit of sherbert on finish.

[on tap at EBF 2008]
Sour patch kids fruit candy aroma with tons of apricot. Almost clear light brown with a white ring. Refreshing fruit flavour, though a bit sweet, alco-pop-ish. Lots of apricot and low bitterness. Medium body, medium carbonation, peppery carbonation almost offsetting a sweet finish.

Bottle from 08 Night of the Funk. Aroma of a field of herbs, a spice shop, restrained in intensity, but amazing in spicy, herbal complexities. Some citrus notes appear also, but the spicier elements are the feature. In the mouth there is a dry, herbal character, very dry in fact, reminiscent of cedar and pine, but also of plenty of other notes foreign/un-nameable to me. Superbly drinkable, and very tantalizing in its uniqueness.

Bottle sampled on 09/26/08 at Night of the Funk.  Pours a dirty light brown with a small white head.  Aroma of maybe sour garlic and lots of spices.  Flavor of the same hard-to-identify spices (ginger? I don’t think it was fir tree...) and a slight tartness.  Interesting beer but also very weird with the crazy spiciness.  Very spicy.  But decent too.

Clear, deep amber pour with a medium foamy off-white head thats gone quickly.  Aroma of not-quite-ripe and sour fruits,  notably cherry, cranberry and apricot.  Some sweet maltiness comes through as well in the nose, and a touch of spice.  Flavor is similarly fruity with a bit of a sweet and sour thing happening.  Very dry on the palate with a bit of herbs on the finish.  Interesting brew.

TAP 140208; MHT 110210; Perhaps bottled in February of 2008; Definitely Sampled in September of 2008
This smells like an old ale as I pour this as it makes me think of aged, oxidized malt.  The beer, when vigorously roused produces an almost two finger thick, fairly quickly dissipating, light tan colored head.  The beer is a red-amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, orange, dark copper hue when held up to the light.  A deeper inspection of the aroma yields an intense, berry like fruitiness, sweet spice notes and a woody-spice / herbal note towards the end.  The perceived Old Ale oxidation, that I noticed as I was pouring this beer, seems to have been a by-product of the particular aromatic components (which was actually sort of what I expected).  The fruit character in the nose is just really intense and along with the sweetness seems to dominate a lot of the complexity that might be more noticeable otherwise.

Wow, the taste was a bit different than I was expecting.  The beer is much drier, almost devoid of sweetness, than the sweet, fruity nose would have suggested and it is actually quite tart as well.  The tartness works with berry-like flavors towards the middle and finish, though the berry notes are not anywhere near as intense as in the aroma.  I would describe the fruitiness in the flavor as a mix of plums, cranberries, blackberries and tart currants.  This has a certain viscousness to it that belies how dry this tastes; I would almost say that the nice tartness helps to mask a bit of sweetness that might otherwise be noticeable.  The finish has a light herbal note to it that seems mostly masked by the noticeable, but not overwhelming tartness.  As the beer warms up, and gets more towards room temperature, some of the sweetness becomes more noticeable, which definitely accentuates a bit more of the berry like fruit notes.

While the flavor is most noticeably tart, this beer is actually quite well balanced and easy drinking.  I can’t help but think this is a bit unnaturally clear, but the head retention is only medium anyway (perhaps from the same cause).  I really like that the intense fruitiness in the aroma, does not drive the flavor to be one dimensional.  Perhaps a bit subtle in its herbal character for a Gruit, but I have a feeling this was true of the true Gruit ales anyway; with the sourness, there is just enough herbal notes to provide a balance for the sweet & fruity notes.  Quite tasty & I would be quite happy drinking quite a bit more of this.

Purchased: Papago Brewing Co, Scottsdale AZ

(bottle) Pours hazy orange with a small white head.  Aroma is buttered sweet corn right off the bat, with touches of vinegar coming in upon warming.  The taste is lightly sour, but there’s more sweetness to this, which imparts somewhat of an unripened peach or nectarine character to the beer.  Lightly dry finish with a medium mouthfeel.

EBF, Copenhagen.
Golden beer, small head. 
A little sourness, lots of fruit, apricots, peaches, cherries. Drier in the finish. Nice experiment.
Tap at EBF: Unclear gold with a off white head. Sour "gløgg" aroma. Sweet fruity - cherries & strawberry. Fruit juice, a bit tart & dry. Very drinkable!

Tap @ EBF, 2008, Carlsberg.
Pours clear golden amber with a nice, small, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is fruity, quite funky, lots of peach and oranges. High carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour is pleasantly tart, fruity with apricot and peach, some melons as well. Light dryness in the finish. Really pleasant, interesting and well-balanced.

A very pleasant surprise. Pours apricot with a tall head that retreats rather swiftly like a theif in the night leaving no evidence at all. Aromas of sour stonefruit. Medium nectar and light on it’s feet with superb carbonation. A mild sour backbone provides the basis of this brew with essence of green peaches, apricots, and nectarines. There is a defined herbal disposition upfront and throughout with glimpses of cedar and tea. The finish is mildly soured. This brew is actually a nice surprise and drinks quite wonderfully. As it warms a note of brown cakebread appears adding to the dimension. This brew is underrated.

Pour is hazy amber with small off white head. Aromas of sour, berries, and some funk. Flavor is tart with berries, malt, and something very different. Never had anything like it before. Interesting...
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle. Hazy amber, small firm head. Sour gooseberry and apple sauce aroma, sweetish and smooth, quite nicely berryish. Same sour berry flavor, little spices and funk. Interesting, but not a total nail.
Draught at European Beer Festival, Copenhagen.  Clear amber, small head. Crystallic malt with some piney tartness. Medium bodied with cookie in mild vinegar. Quite mild, yet odd.

[EBF @ Copenhagen, September 2008] Small fizzy off-white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Somewhat hazy amber color. Aroma was quite spicy with mild sour fruity notes. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and mild dry texture. Moderated acidic flavor with good counter sweetness. Somewhat sour fruity and spicy finish.

600ml bottle. Malty initially on the nose. Fairly sweet. Almost like a barley wine. A mild sourness. Maple syrup and honey. A drier earthy, leafy component in the background. Not picking up any anisse or juniper... the sweeter malt is definitely at the fore. Pours a near still looking cloudy amber. Minimal carbonation and a thin ring of white on top. Flavor is fairly non descript. A good dose of sweeter malt. Drier, leafy hops. Lightly sour and lactic. Oud Brun-esque, but substantially milder. A touch of liquorice as the beer warms. Medium heavy body. Light carbonation with a mostly dry and slightly sour finish.

"Where the Wild Beers Are" 2008.  Sweet and a little sour.  Yeast in the aroma with spices and fruit.  A little sour, almost like a Flemish red.  Still, no carbonation.  Thick and heavy.  It becomes a little sweet as it warms.  Good stuff.
Draught at EBF 2008. Hazy amber, medium yellow beige head. Nutty and fudgy, fruity with notes of plums and blackberries. Slightly acidic, with wooden notes. Moussy mouthfeel. Well balanced.
Fad. EBF 2008. Dejlig sur øl, på den rigtige måde som jeg kan lide. Dvs ikke så sur, men nok til at gøre den frisk. Minder mig om oakwise men ikke så god og kompleks. Men stadig en fin fin øl.
At EBF 2008, Friday September 12Shady copper color, whtie head. Fresh sweet malty scent. Fruity and a bit acidic taste, also harsh. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells lactic and citrussy with some resiny undertones.  Tastes of juniper, some fruity hints, citrus, some creamy hints, and a tarte lactic finish.  Enjoyable.

From the bottle pours cloudy mahogany with a small khaki head. Sour nose, lots of fruit and spice. Hints of tart berries, dry and mildly acidic, soft hint of strawberry in there as well. Sweeter up front sort of like a flemish brown, but without the darker malt flavors, more siding fruity-sweet. Interesting beer with a lot of flavors, although for the price there are others I would pick up over this.
Light hazy orange colour with an off white head. Malty, tart fruity, anise spicy aroma with sweet berry notes. Tart fruity flavor, light dusty and spicy notes.

600ml bottle. Poured a deep golden in color with a medium sized white head that left little lacing on the glass. Aroma is spiced, with note of anise, dark fruits, and some tart.  Tastes is fairly tart with notes of some juniper berries, anise, citrus, herbs, cloves and some dark fruits.  Some complex herbal flavors present. Pricey brew, but I was glad to try it.

60 cl. Clear darkish copper with a lasting 1/8 inch ring. Aroma is tart apple, light spice, and overripe fruits with some acetic acid notes. Flavors of soured raisins and plums (again with near-vinegar notes), light caramel, alcohol and maybe some wood. Mostly just overripe, soured fruit. Light-medium body is dry and warming. I would recommend Anders keep Sam out of the brewery; he (Anders) makes much better brews by himself.

(600ml bottle, thanks CaptainCougar) Cloudy amber body with small off-white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, plum, orange, light alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, plum, orange, some alcohol, fairly sour (fruit).  Medium sweet, some acidity.
600mL bottle. Cloudy orange with a medium head. Aroma of soured fruit (apples and cherries), caramel and lemon zest. Medium to full body. Tangy, fruity finish. Interesting beer.

Bottle from captaincougar. Hazy amber body with a small white head. The nose is sweet and fruity with tart red fruits, caramel and spice. The flavor is lightly sweet, lightly tart with red berries, caramel, raisins, light citrus and wood. Medium body is round with moderate carbonation.

600mL bottle, courtesy of CaptainCougar.  Thanks, Tom!  Pours a slightly hazy, golden-orange color; minimal retention.  Lots of citric tartness, sweet and sour notes, and pine in the aroma; nicely soured and intriguing, foresty notes.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of sour citrus, lemons, pitty grapefruit and piney notes upfront; nice oily, tart density in the mouth; carbonation is relaxed; intricate, strange, challenging beer; seems cohesive overall, clearly presented.  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, solid levels of acidity, and lingering citrus tartness.

600ml Bottle:  Aroma is sour and fruity, with some wood and a strong funk/melting plastic tinge.  Smells like a gueuze.  Poured blood-orange in color with a small, off-white head that did not last long.  Cloudy.  Flavor is medium to heavy sour.  Tastes of spices, wood, sour mix, citric acid, fruits, maple syrup, anise, coconut, vanilla, and a touch of vinegar.  Medium body.  Chalky texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Sweet, sour, strange, dry finish.  Very complex aroma and flavor.  It grew on me.

600 ml bottle. Murky copper color, off-white head. Sour aroma with fruity notes. Sour taste with some dark berries, grapefruit and dark malts. Astringent mouthfeel. Complex and well-crafted, but ultimately I find it a bit hard to approach, especially at the relatively high price.
Bottle. A hazy orange beer with a off-white head. The aroma and taste is light sour and acid, spicy and of pine. Medium body with a dry finish.

Bottle from Capone’s.  Pours turbid orange with 2-finger off-white head.  Nose is tart fruit, including cherry, berry, spicy yeast, honey, juniper.  Tastes tart, fruity, with some earthy notes, hops, honey, spice, and orange zest flavors.  The palate is rich, and the mix of ingredients is unique enough that I have never experienced it before.  Very good overall, but not something I’d regularly drink.

Bazy copper color with a medium head.  Berry and vanilla aroma, with lots of sweet malt.  Good lord, the flavors... Apple and orange; brown sugar and sweet malt; cloves, alspice, nutmeg; very herbal; light sour and tartness.  This is incredible.

Bottle hazy orange color with nice white head. Smells of rhubarb, citrus and pine. Taste is sweet and sour at the same time, nice balance between spices on this one too. Havent really had anything similar so far. Wish it wouldt be so espensive..
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2008 Interesting, unique aroma of sour fruitiness, herbs, spices, mint. Malty, sour flavor of herbs and spices, fruits, some mint and eucalyptus.
On tap @ Ølfestival Aarhus 2008. Hazy amber coloured with a medium sized head. Wow this was quite the surprise. Very good. Nice balance - sour notes - spices - malt and pines.

Draught @ Ølfestival Aarhus 2008.Unclear medium amber red orange color with a average, frothy, good lancing, mostly diminishing, off-white to beige head. Aroma is fruity, orange - mandarin. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet, moderate bitter and vinegar notes with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. (170508)

Hazy orange colour with a medium moslty diminishing white head. Aroma is very strange fresh, piny and sweet. Flavour is very strange, it has sweetness and sourness with a touch of vinegar. Too expensive.
Draught at ÅBF08. Citric aroma, slightly buttery. Cloudy red amber colour. The flavour is also citric. Pine aftertaste. Slightly sweet, in good balance.
Amber beer with a small white head. Fruity floral aroma, has fresh plums, winegum and a little undefined spice. Dry and fruity flavour, very tart and maybe a tad perfumed.

Warm golden with a sour, slightly vinegar like aroma with notes of berries or spice. The flavour is very strange, it has sweetness and sourness with a touch of vinegar and notes of candy sugar, berries and some spruce. I bet the sour-heads like this one.

Draft at Ølfestival, Århus, 2008. A hazy red-amber beer with a thin lazing head. The aroma is malty on a slightly acidic background and combined with strong notes of spices. The flavor is acidic malty with notes of spices, pine,  and star anise, leading to a dry and very tart finish. Why, oh why, is this not sold in Denmark yet?

bottle 660ml at home
Color:orange bit hazy
Scent: sour, dried fruits
Taste:interesting sweet and sour mixture, not bad at all. Fruitiness and quite strong pleasant sourness. Danish lambic
Draught at Aarhus Ølfestival. Hazy orange colour with a medium moslty diminishing white head. Sour sweet aroma and taste with notes of fruit and citrus. Lasting finish.

Århus2008. From tap. Pours slight cloudy and orange with a fully diminished white head. Light acidc and woody aroma. Light spiced too, although not imminent at first. Flavour is woody and dry with a light pinewod needle note. Has a solid acidic and bitter finish with a huge mix of spices. Strange and to be honest, I could not drink a full pint of this nor would I ever drink this again.
Murky brown with beige head. Sweet and sour with notes of roasted malt, caramel and berries. Finshes mild sour.
Draught. Medium high white lasting head. Hazy orange body. Spicy herbal fruity aroma. Dinger dominated flavor. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.

Draught at Aarhus Festival. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Ugly amber/orange colour. Light malty riping sour aroma. Salty light bitter astringent sour flavor. Long not pleasent finish. Oily palate.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 Bottle.
Hazy orange red cloured with a medium sized off white ehad.
Light acidic aroma of vanilla, wood, spices and butterscotsch.
Light acidic flavour of vanilla, wood, caramel, spices and fruits.
Tart finish.
Sample at Aarhus beerfestival. Nice head with good duration. Color iamber. Aroma and taste are complex with spices balance with a pleasant and powerfull sourness.

Tap, Ølfestival Aarhus 2008. Pours a amber beer with a white head. The aroma is very strange fresh, piny and sweet. The flavor is also very surprising with some sourness, some spices, fruits and a lot of other flavors. The recipe should be a replicate of a recipe from approx. 1400, found in Odense (hence the name). The beer has no hops, but still gives a balanced and interesting beer. Try it if you dare, it is good.
Draught at  Århus Ølfestival 2008. Amber - white head. Nice sourness, spicy, crispy body, acid, fruity, dryness, a bit strange - but I like it.

Ølfestival, Aarhus, DK.
On tap. 170508.
Complex spiciness and herb character.

Dark amber colored with little vanishing yellow head. Sourness dominates this fruity and berry aroma with weird piny herbal touch. Medium bodied. Flavor starts with some sweet caramel, but aftertaste is dry with lingonberies dominating, tastes lot like lingonberry juice I had when I was younger.  Rather high carbonation.
(Bottle on 2008-04-30) Amber colour. A bit reddish head. Malty and yeasty nose. Sour and acidic palate. Grapefruit in rather sour taste. Some sweetness. Very interesting.

Bottled. Brownish amber colour with mediumsized off white head, that settles for a rather small one quite quickly. Aroma is sweetish sour along with some fruits,berries, some glue and melted plastic. Also some wooden and vanillaish notes as it warms up. Flavour is quite acidic and sour fruits along with some berries and vanillaish notes. Some underlying wood and alcohol too. Flavour is kind of sour ale meets the alcohol of the big ABV Avery beers. Quite interesting, and might mellow up a bit with age.

0.6 l bottle. Hazy orange amber color, fizzy but head vanishes quickly.  Sweet and sour aroma with glue, orange, honey, berries and pine resin. Sweet and fairly acidic flavor with honey and strong berryish note (gooseberry?). Gets more acidic towards finish with a weird spicy and candyish note.  Medium bodied yet oddly chewy and sticky palate. There are elements which I like (acidity, berries) and which I dont like (glue, palate). Maybe still too young, the aromas and flavors does not seem fully integrated.

Bottled (tap 140208) This bottle was very expensive in Finland: 11,45 euros! Orange amber color, vanishing head. Sourish, sweet aroma: glue, birch leaves,  berries and herbs. Liquerish palate, low carbonation - flat mouthfeel. Lambic-like sour brew. Licorice-anise -flavors are dominating at first, but has lots of interesting berry flavors too: at least sea-buckthorns and lingonberries. Hints of sweeter berries in the aftertaste. Not really alcoholic or hoppy. This is very much traditional ale - you never know what you get!

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 Bottle. Sampled at Tria Fermentation School Scandinavian Craft Brewing class 10/12/07. Poured reddish-orange, with minimal off-white head. Aroma was very sweet with notes of honey, orange, berries, herbs, and anise. Flavor is fairly sour, with  notes of honey and maple syrup, along with some dried fruit, herbs, and pine. Smooth bodied with minimal carbonation, very easy to drink. Really unique and enjoyable; I hope i get the opportunity to try this again.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2008 (Bottled) Clear, reddish amber with a small, almost completely fading, lemonadey head (some yeast in the bottle). Sour-sweetish aroma with lots of berries and fruit, plus cough-syrupy anise and licorice. Very original, fruity and anisey flavor with some lambic-style sourness, sweetish berries, vanilla, hints of tarragon, and low bitterness. Hides the ABV completely, but warms a little. Medium-bodied and slightly sticky with low carbonation - very easy to drink, yet a bit thin. This was pretty weird in December, but now (5 months later) the tartness has grown, flavors blended, and balance improved. Belgian Old Ale is quite an accurate style description. Also reminds me a bit of Innis & Gunn Rum Cask.
